article_title: U.S. Supreme Court Justice Scalia found dead at West Texas ranch
article_text:
U.S. Supreme Court Justice Scalia found dead at West Texas ranch Jurist was visiting luxury ranch

Photo: Edward A. Ornelas, Staff / San Antonio Express-News A man guards the entrance to Cibolo Creek Ranch Saturday Feb. 13,...

U.S. Supreme Court Associate Justice Antonin Scalia, a staunch conservative known for his sharp intellect, wit and biting opinions, was found dead of apparent natural causes Saturday on a luxury ranch in West Texas.

article_metadata.description: U.S. Supreme Court Associate Justice Antonin Scalia, a staunch conservative known for his sharp intellect, wit and biting opinions, was found dead of apparent natural causes Saturday on a luxury ranch in West Texas.  The death immediately became an issue in the presidential race and has far-reaching implications for the Supreme Court, which is set to decide cases that include a affirmative action challenge involving the University of Texas and President Barack Obama’s immigration policy.  A gray Cadillac hearse from Alpine Memorial Funeral Home arrived at the ranch Saturday afternoon and left just before 5 p.m. Law enforcement vehicles also entered and exited the ranch, and a helicopter came from the north toward the ranch, which sits on the west side of U.S. Highway 67 between Marfa and Presidio on the U.S.-Mexico border.  Just hours after the body was found, the Marshals Service notified U.S. Attorney Richard Durbin Jr. and U.S. District Judge Orlando Garcia, the chief judge for the sprawling Western District of Texas that includes San Antonio, Waco and Austin and sweeps west along the border to El Paso.  Billionaire Donald Trump called it a loss for the conservative movement, and Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, said it was up to the Senate to “ensure that the next president names his replacement.”  “Kennedy will be more closely watched than ever,” said Gonzalez, a Democrat and former state district judge who served on a Congressional Hispanic Caucus task force that pushed for the confirmation of Associate Justice Sonia Sotomayor.  Heller, Scalia, who opposed abortion, same-sex marriage and affirmative action, also questioned whether a ban on military-style weapons would violate the Second Amendment.
article_metadata.author.name: By Gary Martin, Vianna Davila and Richard A. Marini Staff Writers
